questions.questionText: Why do you think this tree has a big hole in the middle of it? What could have caused this hole?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies multiple plausible causes (decay, rot, animals, weather, disease) and explains how they work together over time to create the hole.
rubric.meets: Student identifies at least one cause of the hole (rot, animals, or weather damage) and provides a simple explanation of how it happened.
rubric.approaching: Student identifies a possible cause but explanation is vague or incomplete; may confuse cause with what is currently in the hole.
rubric.beginning: Student makes a guess about the hole but provides minimal explanation or suggests an unlikely cause with little reasoning.

questions.questionText: Is this tree alive or dead? How do you know?

rubric.exceeds: Student correctly identifies the tree as alive and provides multiple observations (branches with leaves, still growing, bark visible) to support their answer.
rubric.meets: Student correctly identifies the tree as alive and gives at least one clear observation (has branches, has leaves, still growing) as evidence.
rubric.approaching: Student identifies the tree as alive but provides weak or unclear evidence; may note only one feature without fully explaining why it shows the tree is alive.
rubric.beginning: Student's answer is unclear or incorrect; provides little or no observable evidence to support their claim about whether the tree is alive or dead.

questions.questionText: What tiny living things might be living inside that dark hole, and what are they doing there?

rubric.exceeds: Student names specific organisms (bugs, insects, fungi) and explains what they do in the hole (eat the dead wood, break it down, find shelter).
rubric.meets: Student names at least one type of small living thing (bugs, worms, or similar) and explains a simple purpose (eating, living, hiding).
rubric.approaching: Student suggests small living things might be there but description is vague; may name something without explaining what it does.
rubric.beginning: Student's response is unclear or vague about what lives there; provides little or no explanation of what these creatures do.

questions.questionText: If we come back to look at this tree in 10 years, what do you think will be different? What will stay the same?

rubric.exceeds: Student predicts specific changes (hole gets bigger, more decay) and what stays the same (roots, general shape, still alive), showing understanding of slow decomposition.
rubric.meets: Student makes reasonable predictions about change (hole may grow) or what stays the same (tree location, trunk), with simple explanation.
rubric.approaching: Student makes a prediction about the future but lacks detail or clarity; reasoning is incomplete or shows partial understanding of decay.
rubric.beginning: Student's prediction is unclear, unrealistic, or unsupported; shows minimal understanding of how trees change over time.
